abstract: Dan Barry This Land column describes the scene at Bowery House, a hotel in Lower Manhattan that epitomizes the never-ending push and pull between New York City's past and present; examines how the hotel's owners rent the upper renovated floors of the hotel to the affluent and its dingy second floor to the poor and use this juxtaposition of the area's gritty past to its gentrifying present as a marketing tool.
snippet: On the floors above the cramped cubicles housing nine men, the Bowery House offers rooms to the young and stylish seeking a reminder of the area’s gritty past.
lead_paragraph: On the floors above the cramped cubicles housing nine men, the Bowery House offers rooms to the young and stylish seeking a reminder of the area’s gritty past.

headline.main: On Bowery, Cultures Clash as the Shabby Meet the Shabby Chic
headline.seo: At Bowery House Hotel, Flophouse Aesthetic of Old
headline.print_headline: On Bowery, Cultures Clash as the Shabby Meet the Shabby Chic
